title: John Craig (geologist)
text:
John Craig <a href="Geological%20Society%20of%20London">FGS</a> (1796–1880) was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> <a href="geologist">geologist</a> and <a href="lexicographer">lexicographer</a>. He was lecturer in geology at <a href="University%20of%20Strathclyde">Anderson's University</a>, <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, and a <a href="Fellow">Fellow</a> of the <a href="Geological%20Society%20of%20London">Geological Society of London</a>. In 1849 he published a <a href="dictionary">dictionary</a>.
Born at <a href="Airdrie%2C%20North%20Lanarkshire">Airdrie, North Lanarkshire</a>, the son of a <a href="merchant">merchant</a>, Craig had only six months in a local school and began life as a <a href="weaver%20%28occupation%29">weaver</a>. Self-taught, he later kept a school at <a href="Shotts">Shotts</a> and another at Echo Bank, <a href="Newington%2C%20Edinburgh">Newington</a>, and began to write and publish <a href="poetry">poetry</a>. He next studied <a href="geology">geology</a> and won a prize of the <a href="Royal%20Highland%20and%20Agricultural%20Society%20of%20Scotland">Highland Society</a> for geological work in <a href="Lanarkshire">Lanarkshire</a>. From this, he gained work for the <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> <a href="Town%20Council">Town Council</a> making surveys of public and private property and began to give lectures on geology and to write geological <a href="treatise">treatise</a>s. He became a frequent contributor to the <a href="liberalism">liberal</a> <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a>s in Glasgow.
The new "Craig's Universal dictionary" was issued in two volumes of 1,000 pages each, and also in monthly parts.
Craig died in 1880.
